qa.question: What is a continuous random variable?
options: A variable that takes only countable, distinct values
A variable that can take any value within an interval
A variable that can only take integer values
A variable that is always normally distributed
qa.describe: A continuous random variable can assume any value in a given interval, as mentioned in the module.

qa.question: Which of the following is an example of a continuous random variable?
options: The number of students in a classroom
The number of cars in a parking lot
The number of pages in a book
qa.describe: Weight is a continuous measure since it can take any value within a range.

qa.question: Continuous random variables assume values from which kind of interval?
options: An interval of the form [a, b]
qa.describe: They assume values from an interval [a, b] where any value is possible.

qa.question: How many possible values can a continuous random variable have?
options: An infinite number of values in an interval
qa.describe: Continuous random variables have an infinite number of values within a given interval.

qa.question: Which measurement is typically modeled as a continuous random variable?
qa.describe: Temperature is measured on a continuous scale and can take any value in an interval.

qa.question: Continuous random variables are defined on intervals; which interval is commonly used?
options: An interval [a, b] with endpoints a and b
An interval of whole numbers only
qa.describe: They are defined on an interval [a, b], where a and b are the endpoints of the range.

qa.question: Can continuous random variables be measured with arbitrary precision?
options: Yes, they can be measured to any level of detail
No, they are limited to a few decimal places
Only if they are normally distributed
qa.describe: They can be measured with arbitrary precision because their values are not restricted to specific points.

qa.question: How do continuous random variables differ from discrete random variables?
options: They take on a finite set of values
They assume only prime number values
They can take any value within an interval
They are only used in theoretical mathematics
qa.describe: Continuous random variables differ by taking any value within an interval rather than distinct separate values.

qa.question: What makes continuous data different from categorical data?
options: Continuous data is measured on a continuous scale
Continuous data has only two categories
qa.describe: Continuous data is measured on a scale where every value in an interval is possible.

qa.question: Is weight considered a continuous random variable?
qa.describe: Weight is a continuous random variable because it can take any value within a range.

qa.question: Are time measurements usually treated as continuous random variables?
options: Yes, because time can be divided infinitely
qa.describe: Time is typically treated as continuous since it can be measured with arbitrary precision.

qa.question: Can a continuous random variable take any value within its interval?
options: Yes, any value within the interval is possible
No, it can only take specific predetermined values
qa.describe: Any value within the interval is possible for a continuous random variable.

qa.question: Do continuous random variables assume only integer values?
options: Yes, they are limited to integers
No, they can assume fractional and irrational values too
qa.describe: They are not limited to integers; they include fractional and irrational values within an interval.

qa.question: What type of data is best represented by continuous random variables?
qa.describe: Measurement data, like height or temperature, is best represented by continuous random variables.

qa.question: What does the term 'continuous' imply about the possible values of the random variable?
options: They are uncountably infinite over an interval
qa.describe: It implies that the random variable can take uncountably infinite values within an interval.

qa.question: What does the probability density function (PDF) represent for a continuous random variable?
options: The exact value of the variable
The probability of the variable taking a specific value
The density of probability over an interval
The cumulative probability from negative infinity
qa.describe: The PDF represents the density of probability over an interval for continuous variables.

qa.question: Which condition must a PDF satisfy for all x?
options: f(x) is always positive or zero
qa.describe: The PDF must satisfy f(x) ≥ 0 for all x to be valid.

qa.question: What is the value of the integral of a valid PDF over the entire real line?
qa.describe: The integral of the PDF over its entire range must equal 1.

qa.question: In the expression p(x ≤ X ≤ x + dx) = f(x) dx, what does f(x) dx represent?
options: The probability of X equaling x exactly
The approximate probability that X falls in the interval [x, x+dx]
The cumulative distribution up to x
qa.describe: It represents the approximate probability that X falls within the interval [x, x+dx].

qa.question: What is the probability that a continuous random variable X equals a specific value a?
qa.describe: For a continuous random variable, the probability at any specific point is 0.

qa.question: How do you calculate the probability that X falls between a and b using the PDF?
qa.describe: The probability is calculated by integrating the PDF from a to b.

qa.question: What condition ensures that f(x) is a valid PDF regarding its sign?
options: f(x) must be negative for some x
f(x) must be positive or zero for all x
f(x) can alternate between negative and positive
qa.describe: A valid PDF must be non-negative for all x.

qa.question: How is the probability p(a ≤ X ≤ b) expressed in terms of the PDF?
qa.describe: It is given by the integral of f(x) from a to b.

qa.question: Why must the integral of f(x) over the entire real line equal 1?
options: To guarantee the function is differentiable
To make f(x) a cumulative function
qa.describe: The total probability must be 1, which is achieved by normalizing the PDF.

qa.question: Can f(x) be negative for some values of x in a valid PDF?
options: Yes, as long as the total integral is 1
No, it must always be non-negative
qa.describe: f(x) must be non-negative for all x in a valid probability density function.

qa.question: What does the property p(x = a) = 0 imply for continuous distributions?
options: The probability of any single point is zero
The PDF is zero at x = a
qa.describe: It implies that the probability of the variable taking any exact value is zero.

qa.question: How does a PDF differ from a probability mass function (PMF)?
options: PDFs are used for continuous variables while PMFs are for discrete variables
PDFs always sum to 1 while PMFs integrate to 1
PMFs are only used for normal distributions
qa.describe: PDFs apply to continuous variables and PMFs to discrete ones.

qa.question: Can the value f(x) be directly interpreted as the probability of X = x?
options: Yes, it is the probability at x
No, it is a density that must be integrated
Yes, if x is an integer
No, because f(x) is always zero
qa.describe: The value f(x) is a density, not a probability, and must be integrated over an interval.

qa.question: Which result shows that the probability at an exact point is zero in continuous distributions?
options: Result 1: p(a ≤ X ≤ b) = ∫_a^b f(x) dx
The definition of the cumulative distribution function
qa.describe: Result 2 directly states that p(x = a) is 0 for continuous random variables.

qa.question: What does the expression p(x ≤ X ≤ x+dx) = f(x) dx indicate?
options: That f(x) dx is the exact probability for x
That f(x) dx approximates the probability over an infinitesimal interval
That f(x) dx is the cumulative distribution
That f(x) dx must always equal 1
qa.describe: It indicates that f(x) dx approximates the probability of X falling in the tiny interval from x to x+dx.

qa.question: What is the definition of the distribution function Fₓ(x)?
qa.describe: Fₓ(x) is defined as the cumulative probability P(X ≤ x).

qa.question: How is the cumulative distribution function (CDF) calculated from the PDF?
options: By integrating the PDF from x to infinity
By integrating the PDF from -∞ to x
By taking the logarithm of the PDF
qa.describe: The CDF is obtained by integrating the PDF from -∞ to x.

qa.question: What does Fₓ(x) represent?
options: The probability that X is greater than x
The probability that X is exactly x
The cumulative probability that X is less than or equal to x
qa.describe: Fₓ(x) gives the cumulative probability that X is less than or equal to x.

qa.question: In probability terms, what does Fₓ(x) denote?
qa.describe: Fₓ(x) denotes the probability that X is less than or equal to x.

qa.question: What is the lower limit of the integral in the definition of Fₓ(x)?
qa.describe: The integral starts at -∞, covering the entire lower tail of the distribution.

qa.question: How do you compute the probability that X is less than or equal to x?
options: By integrating f(x) from -∞ to x
By summing f(x) for all values greater than x
qa.describe: You compute it by integrating the PDF from -∞ to x.

qa.question: Is the distribution function Fₓ(x) a non-decreasing function?
qa.describe: The CDF is non-decreasing because probabilities accumulate as x increases.

qa.question: What is the value of Fₓ(-∞)?
qa.describe: Fₓ(-∞) is 0 since no probability accumulates below negative infinity.

qa.question: What is the value of Fₓ(∞)?
qa.describe: Fₓ(∞) equals 1 because the total probability sums to one.

qa.question: What is another name for the distribution function Fₓ(x)?
qa.describe: It is also called the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

qa.question: Does Fₓ(x) provide the probability for a single value or a cumulative event?
options: A cumulative event up to x
qa.describe: Fₓ(x) provides the cumulative probability for all values up to x.

qa.question: Which function gives the total probability accumulated up to a point x?
qa.describe: The CDF gives the total accumulated probability up to a given x.

qa.question: How does Fₓ(x) relate to the area under the PDF curve?
options: It equals the derivative of the area
It is the area under the PDF curve from -∞ to x
It is unrelated to the area
It gives the peak of the PDF
qa.describe: Fₓ(x) is exactly the area under the PDF curve from -∞ to x.

qa.question: Can the distribution function Fₓ(x) be used to determine the median of a distribution?
options: Yes, by finding the x for which Fₓ(x)=0.5
No, it only gives variance information
qa.describe: The median is the value of x that satisfies Fₓ(x) = 0.5.

qa.question: Which integral expression gives the cumulative probability for a continuous random variable?
qa.describe: The cumulative probability is given by ∫ from -∞ to x of f(t) dt.

qa.question: What is the arithmetic mean of a continuous probability distribution?
qa.describe: The arithmetic mean is calculated as E(x) = ∫₋∞^∞ x f(x) dx.

qa.question: How is the expected value E(x) of a continuous random variable calculated?
options: By summing all possible x values
By integrating x multiplied by the PDF over all x
By integrating the PDF only over positive x values
qa.describe: The expected value is computed by integrating x times the PDF over the entire range.

qa.question: What condition must the median M of a continuous distribution satisfy?
qa.describe: The median is the value for which the cumulative probability equals ½.

qa.question: How is the rth central moment μᵣ defined?
qa.describe: The rth central moment is given by μᵣ = ∫₋∞^∞ (x - E(x))ʳ f(x) dx.

qa.question: How is the variance of a continuous random variable defined?
qa.describe: The variance is the second central moment, calculated as ∫₋∞^∞ (x - E(x))² f(x) dx.

qa.question: What integral represents the second central moment (variance) of the distribution?
qa.describe: The second central moment, or variance, is given by ∫₋∞^∞ (x - E(x))² f(x) dx.

qa.question: What does a moment about the mean describe in a probability distribution?
options: The central tendency of the distribution
The spread or variability of the distribution
The maximum value of the distribution
qa.describe: Moments about the mean, particularly the second moment, describe the spread of the distribution.

qa.question: How is the first quartile Q₁ of a distribution determined using the PDF?
options: By finding the mode of the distribution
qa.describe: The first quartile is found by setting ∫₋∞^Q₁ f(x) dx equal to ¼.

qa.question: What is the significance of the median in a probability distribution?
options: It is the most frequently occurring value
It divides the distribution into two equal halves
qa.describe: The median divides the distribution so that half the probability lies below and half above it.

qa.question: How can higher order moments be useful in understanding a distribution's shape?
options: They provide information about skewness and kurtosis
They eliminate the need for variance
qa.describe: Higher order moments help describe aspects like skewness and kurtosis of the distribution.

qa.question: Which moment gives a measure of the spread in the distribution?
qa.describe: The second central moment, or variance, provides a measure of the spread in the distribution.

qa.question: Is the arithmetic mean the same as the expected value in continuous distributions?
options: Only when the distribution is symmetric
qa.describe: In continuous distributions, the arithmetic mean and the expected value are the same.

qa.question: How can the median be determined from the PDF?
options: By finding the value that maximizes f(x)
By integrating f(x) from M to ∞
qa.describe: The median is found by solving ∫₋∞^M f(x) dx = ½.

qa.question: What role does solving f'(x) = 0 play in analyzing a distribution?
options: It determines the mean of the distribution
It helps in finding the median
It identifies the mode of the distribution
qa.describe: Solving f'(x) = 0 helps identify the mode, which is the peak of the distribution.

qa.question: What is the probability density function of a rectangular distribution?
options: f(x) = 1/(b - a) for a ≤ x ≤ b and 0 otherwise
f(x) = (x - a)/(b - a) for a ≤ x ≤ b
f(x) = 1 for a ≤ x ≤ b and 0 otherwise
qa.describe: The rectangular distribution has a constant PDF of 1/(b-a) between a and b.

qa.question: Over which interval is the rectangular distribution defined?
options: For x in the interval [a, b]
For x greater than a only
qa.describe: It is defined for x in the interval [a, b] and is zero outside this interval.

qa.question: How is the mean of a rectangular distribution computed?
qa.describe: The mean is calculated as the average of a and b, i.e., (a + b)/2.

qa.question: What formula for the variance of a rectangular distribution is given in the module?
qa.describe: According to the module, the variance is given as ((a - b)²)/2 (with the understanding that (a - b)² equals (b - a)²).

qa.question: What parameters define the rectangular distribution?
qa.describe: The rectangular distribution is defined by the parameters a and b.

qa.question: What is the value of f(x) for x outside the interval [a, b]?
qa.describe: f(x) is 0 for any x that is not in the interval [a, b].

qa.question: Does the rectangular distribution have a constant probability density over its interval?
options: Yes, it is uniform over [a, b]
Yes, but only at the endpoints
qa.describe: The PDF is constant over the interval, making it a uniform or rectangular distribution.

qa.question: How does the rectangular distribution ensure that the total probability equals 1?
options: By having f(x) = 0 for all x
By integrating the constant density 1/(b-a) over [a, b]
qa.describe: The integral of 1/(b-a) over the interval [a, b] equals 1, ensuring proper normalization.

qa.question: What does the term 'rectangular' refer to in this probability distribution?
options: The shape of the histogram of the distribution
The rectangular shape of the sample space
The interval endpoints being rectangular numbers
The fact that the distribution is only used in geometry
qa.describe: It refers to the constant, flat shape of the PDF when graphed, resembling a rectangle.

qa.question: How is the uniformity of the rectangular distribution expressed in its PDF?
qa.describe: The PDF is constant over the interval, which is the defining feature of a uniform distribution.

qa.question: Is the mean of a rectangular distribution located at the center of the interval?
options: No, it is skewed to one end
qa.describe: The mean is exactly at the center, calculated as (a + b)/2.

qa.question: What is the significance of the parameters a and b in the rectangular distribution?
options: They determine the shape and range of the distribution
They are only used for calculating the median
They represent the variance and mean respectively
They only affect the tail behavior
qa.describe: Parameters a and b set the lower and upper bounds, defining the range and shape of the distribution.

qa.question: Compared to a normal distribution, does the rectangular distribution have heavier tails?
qa.describe: The rectangular distribution has lighter tails because it abruptly drops to zero outside [a, b].

qa.question: What is the main characteristic of the PDF shape in a rectangular distribution?
options: It is flat and constant between a and b
qa.describe: The PDF is flat and constant between a and b, forming a rectangle.

qa.question: How does one prove the mean and variance formulas for the rectangular distribution?
options: By integrating the PDF over the interval [a, b]
By using the moment generating function only
qa.describe: The proofs are based on integrating the PDF over the interval [a, b] to obtain the mean and variance.

qa.question: What is the form of the exponential distribution's probability density function?
qa.describe: The exponential distribution is defined by f(x) = θ e^(–θx) as stated in the module.

qa.question: Which parameter characterizes the exponential distribution?
qa.describe: The parameter θ is used to characterize the exponential distribution.

qa.question: How is the mean of an exponential distribution expressed?
qa.describe: The mean of the exponential distribution is given by 1/θ.

qa.question: What is the variance of an exponential distribution according to the module?
qa.describe: The variance is given as 1/θ² for an exponential distribution.

qa.question: In the exponential distribution, how does the parameter θ affect the distribution?
options: A larger θ results in a longer tail
A larger θ results in a smaller mean
θ does not affect the distribution
A larger θ increases the variance
qa.describe: A larger θ decreases the mean (1/θ) and variance (1/θ²), compressing the distribution.

qa.question: Which real-life phenomenon is often modeled by the exponential distribution?
options: The number of phone calls in an hour
The result of rolling a die
qa.describe: The exponential distribution is commonly used to model waiting times between events.

qa.question: What is the relationship between the parameter θ and the expected value in an exponential distribution?
options: The expected value is the reciprocal of θ
θ is the square of the expected value
qa.describe: The expected value is given by 1/θ, meaning it is the reciprocal of θ.

qa.question: Is the exponential distribution memoryless?
options: Yes, the probability of future events is independent of past events
No, it depends on the history
qa.describe: The exponential distribution is memoryless, meaning the probability of an event does not depend on the past.

qa.question: What is the general shape of the exponential distribution's PDF?
qa.describe: The PDF of an exponential distribution is monotonically decreasing.

qa.question: How does the exponential distribution differ from the normal distribution?
options: It is defined only for positive x and is skewed
It has a constant probability density
qa.describe: The exponential distribution is defined for x ≥ 0 and is right-skewed unlike the symmetric normal distribution.

qa.question: If the parameter θ increases in an exponential distribution, what happens to the mean?
qa.describe: Since the mean is 1/θ, an increase in θ leads to a decrease in the mean.

qa.question: What role does the exponential decay factor e^(–θx) play in the PDF?
options: It causes the PDF to increase with x
It ensures the probability density decreases with increasing x
It has no effect on the shape
qa.describe: The factor e^(–θx) ensures that the density decays exponentially as x increases.

qa.question: Does the exponential distribution have a constant probability density over its domain?
options: No, it decreases as x increases
qa.describe: The probability density decreases with increasing x due to the exponential decay.

qa.question: Which integral would you use to find the cumulative probability for an exponential variable?
qa.describe: For the exponential distribution defined for x ≥ 0, you integrate from 0 to x.

qa.question: What happens to the variance of an exponential distribution if the parameter θ is doubled?
qa.describe: Since variance is 1/θ², doubling θ reduces the variance by a factor of 4.

qa.question: What is the probability density function of a normal distribution?
qa.describe: The normal distribution is defined by f(x) = (1/(σ√(2π))) e^(–(x–μ)²/(2σ²)).

qa.question: How is a normally distributed variable denoted?
qa.describe: A normal variable is denoted as X ~ N(μ, σ²), indicating its mean and variance.

qa.question: What are the two parameters of a normal distribution?
qa.describe: The normal distribution is characterized by its mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ).

qa.question: How is the mean of a normal distribution derived from its PDF?
options: E(x) = ∫₋∞^∞ x f(x) dx, which simplifies to μ
qa.describe: By integrating x multiplied by the PDF, the mean simplifies to μ.

qa.question: How is the variance of a normal distribution derived from its PDF?
options: By integrating (x - μ)² f(x) dx, resulting in σ²
By calculating the square of the mean
qa.describe: The variance is found by integrating (x - μ)² f(x) dx, which equals σ².

qa.question: What substitution is typically used to prove the mean of a normal distribution?
qa.describe: The substitution z = (x - μ)/σ is used to simplify the integration.

qa.question: What is the moment generating function (MGF) of a normal distribution?
qa.describe: The MGF of a normal distribution is Mₓ(t) = e^(tμ + ½t²σ²).

qa.question: What property of the normal curve is evident from its symmetry about x = μ?
options: The mean, median, and mode are identical
qa.describe: Its symmetry implies that the mean, median, and mode are all the same.

qa.question: What is the maximum value of the normal distribution's PDF?
qa.describe: The maximum ordinate is given by 1/(σ√(2π)) at x = μ.

qa.question: What do the odd-order central moments of a normal distribution equal?
qa.describe: All odd-order central moments of a normal distribution are zero.

qa.question: How are the even-order central moments of a normal distribution expressed?
qa.describe: They are given by the product 1·3·5···(2r – 1) times σ^(2r).

qa.question: What does the additive property of independent normal variables state?
options: Their sum is not normally distributed
Their sum is normally distributed with summed means and variances
qa.describe: It states that the sum of independent normal variables is also normal, with means and variances added.

qa.question: If X₁ ~ N(μ₁, σ₁²) and X₂ ~ N(μ₂, σ₂²), what is the distribution of X₁ + X₂?
qa.describe: The sum is normally distributed with mean μ₁ + μ₂ and variance σ₁² + σ₂².

qa.question: What is the role of the moment generating function technique in the context of normal distributions?
options: To prove properties like the additive nature of normal distributions
To differentiate between discrete and continuous distributions
qa.describe: The MGF technique is used to prove properties such as the additive property of independent normals.

qa.question: How does a linear combination of independent normal variables behave in terms of distribution?
qa.describe: Any linear combination of independent normal variables is also normally distributed.

qa.question: How is a standard normal variable defined in terms of a normally distributed variable X?
qa.describe: A standard normal variable is defined by standardizing X using Z = (X - μ)/σ.

qa.question: What is the probability density function of a standard normal distribution?
qa.describe: The standard normal distribution has the PDF f(z) = (1/√(2π)) e^(–z²/2).

qa.question: What are the mean and variance of the standard normal distribution?
qa.describe: For a standard normal distribution, the mean is 0 and the variance is 1.

qa.question: What substitution is used to transform a normal variable X into a standard normal variable Z?
qa.describe: The transformation is done by Z = (X - μ)/σ.

qa.question: What is the value of the derivative dx/dz in the standardization process?
qa.describe: When standardizing, dx/dz equals σ.

qa.question: How does the standard normal distribution simplify the PDF of any normal variable?
options: It removes the μ and σ parameters by transforming the variable
It changes the PDF to a discrete function
qa.describe: Standardization removes μ and σ, yielding the universal standard normal form.

qa.question: Why is the standard normal distribution important in statistics?
options: It is used only for discrete data
It provides a basis for comparing different normal distributions
It only applies to small sample sizes
qa.describe: It serves as a reference to compare different normal distributions via standardization.

qa.question: What is the range of a standard normal variable Z?
qa.describe: A standard normal variable can take any real number value.

qa.question: How is the transformation Z = (X - μ)/σ used in practice?
options: To convert any normal variable to the standard normal form
To change a discrete variable into a continuous one
qa.describe: This transformation standardizes any normal variable to the standard normal form.

qa.question: Does the standard normal distribution have a bell-shaped curve?
qa.describe: The standard normal distribution is well known for its bell-shaped curve.

qa.question: What is the significance of standardizing a normal variable?
options: It helps compare different distributions by removing scale differences
qa.describe: Standardizing allows for comparisons across different normal distributions by removing μ and σ.

qa.question: How does the area under the standard normal curve relate to probabilities?
options: The area is not related to probabilities
The area gives the moment generating function
The area shows the distribution's skewness
qa.describe: The area under the curve between two points gives the probability of Z falling within that interval.

qa.question: What is the normalization constant in the standard normal PDF?
qa.describe: The normalization constant ensuring total area equals 1 is 1/√(2π).

qa.question: Can the standard normal distribution be used to compute z-scores?
options: Yes, it is the basis for computing z-scores
No, z-scores come from the exponential distribution
Only when the data is skewed
No, z-scores are computed from the uniform distribution
qa.describe: Z-scores are computed by standardizing values using the standard normal distribution.

qa.question: What notation is used to denote a standard normal distribution?
qa.describe: A standard normal distribution is denoted by Z ~ N(0,1).

2.name: Area Under the Normal Probability Curve

qa.question: How do you find the probability that a normal variable lies between two values?
options: By summing the values of the PDF at those points
By integrating the PDF over the interval
By averaging the values of the PDF at the endpoints
qa.describe: The probability is found by integrating the PDF between the two values.

qa.question: What substitution is used to convert X to a standard normal variable when computing areas?
qa.describe: You standardize by using Z = (X - μ)/σ.

qa.question: What is the purpose of the standard normal table?
options: To provide critical values for t-tests
To look up cumulative probabilities for Z values
To compute moments of the normal distribution
To find the PDF values for any X
qa.describe: The standard normal table is used to look up cumulative probabilities for Z scores.

qa.question: How is the area under the standard normal curve interpreted?
options: As the density at a single point
As the probability of a range of outcomes
As the variance of the distribution
As the mean of the distribution
qa.describe: The area represents the probability of the variable falling within a specified range.

qa.question: What does the area under the normal curve represent?
options: Only the probability of the mean
qa.describe: The total area under the normal curve is 1, representing the total probability.

qa.question: How do you convert a given X value to a z-score?
qa.describe: The conversion is done by computing Z = (X - μ)/σ.

qa.question: What information does the standard normal table provide?
options: The probability density for a given z
Only the z-scores for x values
The mean and variance of Z
qa.describe: It provides cumulative probabilities corresponding to z-scores.

qa.question: Is the area under the normal curve over its entire range equal to 1?
options: It depends on μ and σ
qa.describe: By definition, the total area under the normal curve is 1.

qa.question: Why do we standardize normal variables when calculating probabilities?
options: To simplify calculations using the standard normal table
To change the shape of the distribution
qa.describe: Standardization simplifies probability calculations by using the universal standard normal table.

qa.question: What is the relationship between the cumulative distribution function and the area under the curve?
options: The CDF is the derivative of the area
The CDF equals the area under the PDF from -∞ to x
The CDF is the square of the area
qa.describe: The CDF at a point x equals the area under the PDF from -∞ to x.

qa.question: How can you compute the probability of X being less than a specific value using the standard normal curve?
options: By finding the z-score and looking up the corresponding area in the table
By differentiating the PDF at that value
qa.describe: You convert X to a z-score and then use the standard normal table to find the cumulative probability.

qa.question: What is the significance of the substitution Z = (X - μ)/σ when calculating areas?
options: It transforms the normal distribution to a standard form
It is used to compute the variance
It changes the distribution to exponential
qa.describe: This substitution standardizes the variable, allowing use of the standard normal table.

qa.question: What does the area between 0 and a positive z-value represent?
options: The probability of Z being negative
The probability of Z being exactly zero
The probability that Z falls between 0 and that positive value
qa.describe: It represents the cumulative probability from 0 up to the specified positive z-value.

qa.question: How is the total area under the standard normal curve divided?
options: Equally on both sides of the mean
Unequally, with more area on the right
It is not divided at all
qa.describe: The curve is symmetric, so the area is equally divided on either side of the mean.

qa.question: What method is commonly used to look up probabilities for the standard normal distribution?
qa.describe: The standard normal table is the common tool for looking up cumulative probabilities for Z.
